title: 114_s2558
content: The "Spoofing Prevention Act of 2016" defines terms like "Commission" and "voice service" and expands the prohibition on misleading caller identification information. The "Spoofing Prevention Act of 2016" expands regulations on caller identification for voice and text messaging services, including communications from outside the United States. The "Spoofing Prevention Act of 2016" expands regulations on caller identification for voice and text messaging services, including communications from outside the United States. It defines a text message as a message consisting of text, images, sounds, or other information transmitted or received by a device identified by a 10-digit telephone number, including SMS, EMS, and MMS messages. The "Spoofing Prevention Act of 2016" defines text messaging service as a service that allows the transmission or receipt of a text message, and voice service as any service that provides voice communications to an end user using resources from the North American Numbering Plan. The Truth in Caller ID Act of 2009 is amended to include regulations by the Federal Communications Commission within 18 months of enactment. The amendments will take effect 6 months after the regulations are prescribed. The Commission will publish a report on existing technological solutions to combat misleading or inaccurate caller identification information, including analysis of technologies, descriptions of how they protect consumers, and details on how subscribers can access these technologies. The GAO will provide a report on combating fraudulent caller identification information. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on combating fraudulent caller identification information, examining trends in scams, enforcement actions, and industry efforts to develop standards. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 18 months on combating fraudulent caller identification information, including recommendations for action. The Comptroller General will submit recommendations on combating fraudulent caller identification information. SEC. 6. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. SEC. 6. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. Nothing in this Act shall modify rules related to the Telephone Consumer Protection Act of 1991 or the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003. It also clarifies that text messaging services are not classified as telecommunications services under the Communications Act of 1934. The curr_chunk discusses the classification of VoIP services as telecommunications services under the Communications Act of 1934. It also addresses the authority of the Commission to determine the scope of provisions related to voice services. The curr_chunk mentions VoIP service, non-interconnected VoIP service, or text messaging service.
